title: Netherlands national football team
text:
The Netherlands national football team () has represented the <a href="Netherlands">Netherlands</a> in international men's <a href="Association%20football">football</a> matches since 1905. The national team is controlled by the <a href="Royal%20Dutch%20Football%20Association">Royal Dutch Football Association</a> (KNVB), the governing body for <a href="football%20in%20the%20Netherlands">football in the Netherlands</a>, which is a part of <a href="UEFA">UEFA</a>, and under the jurisdiction of <a href="FIFA">FIFA</a>. They are widely considered one of the best national teams in world football and widely regarded as one of the greatest national teams of all time. Most of the Netherlands' home matches are played at the <a href="Johan%20Cruyff%20Arena">Johan Cruyff Arena</a> and the <a href="De%20Kuip">Stadion Feijenoord</a>.
The team is colloquially referred to as "Het Nederlands Elftal" (The Dutch Eleven) or "Oranje", after the <a href="House%20of%20Orange-Nassau">House of Orange-Nassau</a> and their distinctive orange jerseys. Like the country itself, the team is sometimes (also colloquially) referred to as <a href="Terminology%20of%20the%20Low%20Countries">Holland</a>. The fan club is known as "Het Oranje Legioen" (The Orange Legion).
The Netherlands has competed in ten FIFA World Cups, appearing in the finals three times (in <a href="1974%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1974</a>, <a href="1978%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1978</a> and <a href="2010%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2010</a>). They have also appeared in ten <a href="UEFA%20European%20Championship">UEFA European Championship</a>s, winning the <a href="UEFA%20Euro%201988">1988</a> tournament in West Germany. Additionally, the team won a bronze medal at the <a href="Football%20at%20the%20Summer%20Olympics">Olympic tournament</a> in <a href="Football%20at%20the%201908%20Summer%20Olympics">1908</a>, <a href="Football%20at%20the%201912%20Summer%20Olympics">1912</a> and <a href="Football%20at%20the%201920%20Summer%20Olympics">1920</a>. The Netherlands has long-standing football rivalries with neighbours <a href="Low%20Countries%20derby">Belgium</a> and <a href="Germany%20national%20football%20team">Germany</a>.
History.
Beginnings: 1905–1969.
The Netherlands played their first international match in <a href="Antwerp">Antwerp</a> against <a href="Belgium%20national%20football%20team">Belgium</a> on 30 April 1905. The players were selected by a five-member commission from the Dutch Football Association. After 90 minutes, the score was 1–1. Because the match was for the Coupe van den Abeele it went into overtime, during which <a href="Eddy%20de%20Neve">Eddy de Neve</a> scored three times, making the score 4–1 for the Netherlands. Some historians attribute one of the goals scored to <a href="Willem%20Hesselink">Willem Hesselink</a>.
In 1908, the Netherlands competed in their first official tournament appearance at the <a href="Football%20at%20the%201908%20Summer%20Olympics">Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="London">London</a>. They received a bronze medal after losing to <a href="Great%20Britain%20men%27s%20Olympic%20football%20team">Great Britain</a> in the semifinals, before defeating <a href="Sweden%20national%20football%20team">Sweden</a> in the bronze medal match 2–0. At the Olympic Games in 1912 and 1920, the Dutch finished with the bronze medal as they lost to Denmark and Belgium in the respective tournaments.
The Dutch reached the semi-finals at the <a href="Football%20at%20the%201924%20Summer%20Olympics">1924 Summer Olympics</a> in Paris after winning against <a href="Romania%20national%20football%20team">Romania</a> and <a href="Irish%20Free%20State%20national%20football%20team">Ireland</a>. In the semi-final, they gave up a one-goal lead, scored by <a href="Kees%20Pijl">Kees Pijl</a>, to lose 2–1 versus Uruguay and were relegated to the third-place playoff for the fourth time, losing to Sweden in a replay.
After being eliminated in the first round at the <a href="Football%20at%20the%201928%20Summer%20Olympics">1928 Summer Olympics</a> on home turf, they skipped the first World Cup in 1930 due to the cost of travel from Europe to South America. The team made their first appearance at a <a href="FIFA%20World%20Cup">FIFA World Cup</a> in <a href="1934%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1934</a> where they took on Switzerland. <a href="Kick%20Smit">Kick Smit</a> was the first goalscorer for the Netherlands in a World Cup. The team was eliminated in the opening round by Switzerland 3–2. A second appearance at the <a href="1938%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1938 World Cup</a> resulted in a first-round elimination against <a href="Czechoslovakia%20national%20football%20team">Czechoslovakia</a>.
After the Second World War, the Dutch qualified for only two international tournaments before the 1970s: the <a href="Football%20at%20the%201948%20Summer%20Olympics">1948 Summer Olympics</a> in Great Britain and the <a href="Football%20at%20the%201952%20Summer%20Olympics">1952 Summer Olympics</a> in Finland. They suffered early elimination, losing to the hosts in 1948 and <a href="Brazil%20national%20football%20team">Brazil</a> in 1952.
Total football in the 1970s and first golden generations.
During the 1970s, <a href="total%20football">total football</a> () was invented, pioneered by <a href="AFC%20Ajax">Ajax</a> and led by playmaker <a href="Johan%20Cruyff">Johan Cruyff</a> and national team head coach <a href="Rinus%20Michels">Rinus Michels</a>. The Dutch made significant strides, qualifying for two World Cup finals in the decade. <a href="Carlos%20Alberto%20Torres">Carlos Alberto</a>, captain of the Brazilian team that won the <a href="1970%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1970 FIFA World Cup</a> said, "The only team I've seen that did things differently was Holland at <a href="1974%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">the 1974 World Cup in Germany</a>. Since then everything looks more or less the same to me ... Their 'carousel' style of play was amazing to watch and marvelous for the game."
In 1974, the Netherlands beat both Brazil and <a href="Argentina%20national%20football%20team">Argentina</a> in the second group stage, reaching the final for the first time in their history. However, they lost to <a href="Germany%20national%20football%20team">West Germany</a> in <a href="1974%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20Final">the final</a> in <a href="Munich">Munich</a>, despite having gone up 1–0 through <a href="Johan%20Neeskens">Johan Neeskens</a>' early <a href="Penalty%20kick%20%28association%20football%29">penalty kick</a> before a German had even touched the ball. However, a converted penalty by <a href="Paul%20Breitner">Paul Breitner</a> and the winner from <a href="Gerd%20M%C3%BCller">Gerd Müller</a>, led to a victory for the Germans.
The <a href="UEFA%20Euro%201976">1976 European Championship</a> the Netherlands qualified for their first <a href="UEFA%20European%20Championship">European Championship</a> after beating Belgium in the quarterfinals. They were matched in the semifinals by Czechoslovakia who kept Cruyff and Van Hanegem within arms-length of another player as they defeated the Dutch in extra time. The Dutch finished in third place after defeating the hosts (Yugoslavia) in extra time.
In 1978, the Netherlands qualified for the World Cup in Argentina. The team was missing Johan Cruyff due to a kidnapping attempt, and <a href="Wim%20van%20Hanegem">Wim van Hanegem</a>. But the squad still had players like <a href="Jan%20Jongbloed">Jan Jongbloed</a>, <a href="Wim%20Suurbier">Wim Suurbier</a> and <a href="Ruud%20Krol">Ruud Krol</a> from the previous World Cup. After finishing runner-up in Group 4 behind <a href="Peru%20national%20football%20team">Peru</a>, they recorded wins against Austria and <a href="Italy%20national%20football%20team">Italy</a> to set up <a href="1978%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20Final">a final with Argentina</a>. After a controversial start, with Argentina questioning the plaster cast on <a href="Ren%C3%A9%20van%20de%20Kerkhof">René van de Kerkhof</a>'s wrist, the match headed to extra time where the Dutch lost 3–1 after two <a href="extra%20time">extra time</a> goals from <a href="Mario%20Kempes">Mario Kempes</a> and <a href="Daniel%20Bertoni">Daniel Bertoni</a>.
Failure before European champions.
<a href="UEFA%20Euro%201980">Euro '80</a> was the last tournament for which the Total Football team qualified. Despite the tournament format being expanded that year they did not advance past the group stage as they finished behind Czechoslovakia by goal difference.
Veterans such as Krol and Rensenbrink retired soon afterwards and the Dutch team hit a low point in their history: they missed the <a href="1982%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1982 World Cup</a> in Spain, <a href="UEFA%20Euro%201984">Euro 1984</a> in France, and the <a href="1986%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1986 World Cup</a> in Mexico. They failed qualifying for Euro 1984 by virtue of goals scored when <a href="Spain%20national%20football%20team">Spain</a> scored twelve in the final game against <a href="Malta%20national%20football%20team">Malta</a>. Because both teams had the same goal difference (+16), Spain qualified having scored two more goals than the Dutch. During the qualification stage for the 1986 World Cup the Dutch finished in second place and advanced to the playoffs against neighbours Belgium. After losing the first leg 1–0 in <a href="Brussels">Brussels</a>, they held a 2–0 lead at <a href="Rotterdam">Rotterdam</a> with a few minutes remaining. But <a href="Georges%20Grun">Georges Grun</a>'s header in the 84th minute resulted in the Netherlands elimination as Belgium advanced to the World Cup on <a href="away%20goals%20rule">away goals</a>.
Rinus Michels returned, with his technical assistant <a href="Nol%20de%20Ruiter">Nol de Ruiter</a>, to coach the team for <a href="UEFA%20Euro%201988">Euro 1988</a> in West Germany. After losing the first group match against the <a href="Soviet%20Union%20national%20football%20team">Soviet Union</a> (1–0), the Netherlands qualified for the semi-final by defeating <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England</a> 3–1 (with a hat-trick by the tournament's top scorer <a href="Marco%20van%20Basten">Marco van Basten</a>), and the <a href="Republic%20of%20Ireland%20national%20football%20team">Republic of Ireland</a> (1–0). For many Dutch football supporters, the most important match in the tournament was the semi-final against West Germany, the host country, considered as revenge for the 1974 World Cup final (also in West Germany). Van Basten scored in the 89th minute to sink the German side. The Netherlands won the final with a victory over the USSR with a header by <a href="Ruud%20Gullit">Ruud Gullit</a> and a volley by Van Basten. This was the national team's first major tournament win.
The Netherlands was one of the favourites for the <a href="1990%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1990 World Cup</a> tournament in Italy until <a href="Thijs%20Libregts">Thijs Libregts</a> was replaced by <a href="Leo%20Beenhakker">Leo Beenhakker</a> in a late management switch. After this, the Dutch scored only two goals in the group stage which featured England, <a href="Egypt%20national%20football%20team">Egypt</a> and the Republic of Ireland. After finishing the group stage with identical records, the Netherlands and the Republic of Ireland drew lots to determine which team would finish second. The Netherlands had the tougher draw against West Germany, while the Republic of Ireland took Romania. The match against West Germany is mostly remembered for the spitting incident involving <a href="Frank%20Rijkaard">Frank Rijkaard</a> and <a href="Rudi%20V%C3%B6ller">Rudi Völler</a> as the Netherlands were defeated 2–1.
The team reached the semifinals in the <a href="UEFA%20Euro%201992">Euro 1992</a> in Sweden, which was noted for the emergence of <a href="Dennis%20Bergkamp">Dennis Bergkamp</a>. They were eliminated by eventual champions <a href="Denmark%20national%20football%20team">Denmark</a>, however, when <a href="Peter%20Schmeichel">Peter Schmeichel</a> saved Van Basten's kick in the penalty shootout. This was Van Basten's last major tournament. He suffered a serious ankle injury shortly after, and eventually retired at age 30 in 1995. It was also the last hurrah for Rinus Michels, who returned for one final spell in charge of the team before retiring for good after the tournament ended.
<a href="Dick%20Advocaat">Dick Advocaat</a> took over from Michels on the understanding that he would be replaced by Johan Cruyff the following year. But after talks between Cruyff and the KNVB broke down, Advocaat remained in charge of the national team for the World Cup. In the <a href="1994%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1994 World Cup</a> in the United States, in the absence of the injured Van Basten and the <a href="Striker%20%28association%20football%29">striker</a> Ruud Gullit, Dennis Bergkamp led the team with three goals and the Netherlands advanced to the quarter-finals, where they lost 3–2 to eventual champions Brazil.
Second golden generations: 1996–2014.
After finishing second in their <a href="UEFA%20Euro%201996">Euro 1996</a> group, they played <a href="France%20national%20football%20team">France</a> in the quarter-finals. With the score nil all, the match went to penalties. <a href="Clarence%20Seedorf">Clarence Seedorf</a>'s shot in the fourth round was stopped by French goalkeeper <a href="Bernard%20Lama">Bernard Lama</a>, but the goal by Laurent Blanc eliminated the Netherlands. After they finished top of the <a href="1998%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%E2%80%93%20UEFA%20Group%207">qualifying group</a>, they were drawn in Group E of the <a href="1998%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1998 World Cup</a>. With the Dutch team featuring Dennis Bergkamp, <a href="Marc%20Overmars">Marc Overmars</a>, <a href="Phillip%20Cocu">Phillip Cocu</a>, <a href="Edgar%20Davids">Edgar Davids</a>, <a href="Frank%20de%20Boer">Frank de Boer</a>, <a href="Ronald%20de%20Boer">Ronald de Boer</a> and Kluivert, they reached the semifinals where they again lost on penalties, this time to Brazil. Falling behind early in the second half before an 87th-minute goal from <a href="Patrick%20Kluivert">Patrick Kluivert</a> gave the Dutch fans hope, they lost 4–2 on penalties, and then lost the third-place playoff to <a href="Croatia%20national%20football%20team">Croatia</a>. Soon afterwards, manager <a href="Guus%20Hiddink">Guus Hiddink</a> resigned to be replaced by Frank Rijkaard. The Netherlands co-hosted <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202000">Euro 2000</a> with Belgium and won all three games in the group stage and then defeated <a href="Serbia%20and%20Montenegro%20national%20football%20team">FR Yugoslavia</a> 6–1 in the quarter-finals. In the semifinals, Italian goalkeeper <a href="Francesco%20Toldo">Francesco Toldo</a> made two penalty shootout saves to eliminate the Netherlands. The team failed to qualify for the <a href="2002%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2002 World Cup</a> after crucial losses to <a href="Portugal%20national%20football%20team">Portugal</a> and the Republic of Ireland, prompting manager <a href="Louis%20van%20Gaal">Louis van Gaal</a> to resign.
Dick Advocaat became the national coach for the Netherlands for the second time in January 2002. His first match was a 1–1 draw against England in Rotterdam. The national team finished second place in their <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202004%20qualifying%20Group%203">qualifying group</a> for the <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202004">2004 Euros</a>. Having to play in the playoffs after losing to the Czech Republic, they knocked off <a href="Scotland%20national%20football%20team">Scotland</a> with a 6–0 win in the second leg to qualify for the 2004 tournament. The tournament saw the Dutch make it to the semifinals where they lost to the hosts in Portugal. Heavy criticism of his handling of the national team lead Advocaat to quit.
The Netherlands qualified for the <a href="2006%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2006 World Cup</a> under new manager Marco van Basten. They were eliminated in the second round after losing 1–0 to Portugal. The match produced 16 <a href="Fouls%20and%20misconduct%20%28association%20football%29">yellow cards</a>, matching the World Cup record for most cautions in one game set in 2002, and set a new World Cup record of <a href="Fouls%20and%20misconduct%20%28association%20football%29">four red cards</a>, two per side; it was nicknamed "the <a href="Battle%20of%20Nuremberg%20%282006%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%29">Battle of Nuremberg</a>" by the press. Despite criticism surrounding his selection policy and the lack of attacking football from his team, Van Basten was offered a two-year extension to his contract by the KNVB. This allowed him to serve as national coach during <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202008">Euro 2008</a> and the <a href="2010%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2010 World Cup</a>. The Netherlands qualified for Euro 2008, where they were drawn in the "<a href="Group%20of%20Death">Group of Death</a>", together with France, Italy and Romania. They began with a 3–0 win over world champions Italy in <a href="Bern">Bern</a>, their first victory over the Italians since 1978. They then beat France by 4–1 to qualify for the second round, and went on winning the group on nine points after beating Romania 2–0 with (mainly) their reserve players. However, they then lost in the quarter-finals to Guus Hiddink's <a href="Russia%20national%20football%20team">Russia</a> 3–1, with <a href="Ruud%20van%20Nistelrooy">Ruud van Nistelrooy</a> scoring an 86th-minute equaliser to force extra time, where the Russians scored twice. Following the tournament, Van Basten resigned having accepted the role at Ajax.
Under new coach <a href="Bert%20van%20Marwijk">Bert van Marwijk</a>, the Dutch went on to secure a 100% record in <a href="2010%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%26amp%3Bnbsp%3B%E2%80%93%20UEFA%20Group%209">their World Cup 2010 qualification campaign</a> to qualify for the World Cup. After they had comfortably qualified with maximum points in Group E and <a href="Slovakia%20national%20football%20team">Slovakia</a> in the round of 16, they took on Brazil in the quarter-finals. After trailing 1–0 at half-time, <a href="Wesley%20Sneijder">Wesley Sneijder</a> scored two goals in the second half to advance the team to the semis where they beat <a href="Uruguay%20national%20football%20team">Uruguay</a> 3–2. They advanced to their first World Cup final since 1978 but <a href="2010%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20Final">fell to Spain 1–0</a> after midfielder <a href="Andr%C3%A9s%20Iniesta">Andrés Iniesta</a> scored in extra time. From August to September 2011, the team was ranked number one in the <a href="FIFA%20World%20Rankings">FIFA World Rankings</a>, becoming the second national football team, after Spain, to top the rankings without previously winning a World Cup.
For <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202012">Euro 2012</a>, the Netherlands were placed in Group B with Germany, Portugal and Denmark, dubbed the tournament's "Group of Death". The Netherlands lost all three of its matches. Dutch football legend Johan Cruyff criticised the team's star players for poor build up play and sloppy execution of the easy passes. Manager Bert van Marwijk resigned after the disappointment.
Louis van Gaal became the manager for the second time. In the <a href="2014%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%28UEFA%29">2014 World Cup UEFA qualifying round</a>, the Netherlands won nine games and drew one, topping the group and earning automatic qualification. They were drawn into <a href="2014%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20Group%20B">Group B</a>, alongside Spain, <a href="Chile%20national%20football%20team">Chile</a> and <a href="Australia%20national%20soccer%20team">Australia</a>. The team avenged their 2010 defeat by defeating title holders Spain 5–1 in their opening match, with <a href="Robin%20van%20Persie">Robin van Persie</a> and <a href="Arjen%20Robben">Arjen Robben</a> scoring two goals each and <a href="Stefan%20de%20Vrij">Stefan de Vrij</a> the other.
After finishing top of Group B, the Dutch defeated <a href="Mexico%20national%20football%20team">Mexico</a> 2–1 in the round of 16, with Wesley Sneijder equalising late in the match and <a href="Klaas-Jan%20Huntelaar">Klaas-Jan Huntelaar</a> scoring a controversial penalty after a foul on Arjen Robben in stoppage time. In the quarter-finals, where they faced <a href="Costa%20Rica%20national%20football%20team">Costa Rica</a>, the Dutch had many shots on goal but could not score; the match finished in a 0–0 draw after extra time. The Netherlands won the ensuing penalty shootout 4–3. This was due in large part to backup goalkeeper <a href="Tim%20Krul">Tim Krul</a> who was brought on just before the end of extra time and made two saves. This marked the first time in World Cup history a goalkeeper was brought onto the field solely to participate in a shootout.
The semi-final against Argentina saw the Netherlands having a good chance to score from Arjen Robben while containing <a href="Lionel%20Messi">Lionel Messi</a> as it remained scoreless after extra time. However, in penalty kicks, the Dutch were eliminated 4–2, with <a href="Ron%20Vlaar">Ron Vlaar</a> and Wesley Sneijder having their spot kicks saved by <a href="Sergio%20Romero">Sergio Romero</a>. The Netherlands won the third-place match against hosts Brazil. Van Gaal, who successfully motivated the team after their semi-final elimination, received praise for getting more out of the young and inexperienced Netherlands squad than many expected.
Decline and recovery: 2014–present.
Guus Hiddink followed Van Gaal as manager for the <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202016%20qualifying">Euro 2016 qualifying</a> campaign. On 29 June 2015, Hiddink resigned and was succeeded by assistant <a href="Danny%20Blind">Danny Blind</a>. The Netherlands finished fourth in their group failing to qualify for the European Championship for the first time since 1984, and missing a major tournament for the first time since the 2002 World Cup. The team's poor form continued into the <a href="2018%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%28UEFA%29">2018 World Cup qualifiers</a>, eventually resulting in Blind being dismissed after a 2–0 defeat to <a href="Bulgaria%20national%20football%20team">Bulgaria</a> in March 2017. After the return of Dick Advocaat as coach, the Netherlands failed to qualify for the <a href="2018%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2018 FIFA World Cup</a>, finishing third in <a href="2018%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%E2%80%93%20UEFA%20Group%20A">Group A</a> behind France and <a href="Sweden%20national%20football%20team">Sweden</a>.
In February 2018, Advocaat was replaced by <a href="Ronald%20Koeman">Ronald Koeman</a>, on a contract until the summer of 2022. The Netherlands qualified for League A in the <a href="2018%E2%80%9319%20UEFA%20Nations%20League">UEFA Nations League</a> where they would qualify to the final four after drawing with Germany on the final match day, beating France by head-to-head records. The Dutch team beat <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England</a> in the semi-final of the Nations League, but lost 1–0 in the final against <a href="Portugal%20national%20football%20team">Portugal</a>.
The Netherlands qualified for the <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202020">UEFA Euro 2020 Championships</a> on 16 November 2019 after drawing against <a href="Northern%20Ireland%20national%20football%20team">Northern Ireland</a>, marking their tenth participation in the UEFA Euro championships. Following the qualification, Ronald Koeman resigned from the team to coach <a href="FC%20Barcelona">FC Barcelona</a>, eventually to be succeeded by <a href="Frank%20de%20Boer">Frank de Boer</a>.
Without Ronald Koeman in charge, the Dutch struggled in the new <a href="2020%E2%80%9321%20UEFA%20Nations%20League%20A">Nations League</a> season, where they joined Poland, <a href="Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina%20national%20football%20team">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a> and Italy. The Netherlands won 1–0 at home by courtesy of <a href="Steven%20Bergwijn">Steven Bergwijn</a> after a difficult game where Poland played very defensive against the Netherlands. However, also at the home ground, the Dutch fell by the same score to Italy and lost their leading position to the Italians as well. Eventually, the Dutch improved, and obtained important wins over Bosnia at home and Poland away, but a disappointing away draw to Bosnia proved crucial. Despite a strong display in their last group match against Italy, the match in Bergamo resulted in yet another draw. The Netherlands came within a point of progressing but eventually failed to acquire the ticket for the <a href="2021%20UEFA%20Nations%20League%20Finals">2021 UEFA Nations League Finals</a>.
At <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202020">Euro 2020</a>, the Dutch played their group matches at home at the Johan Cruijff Arena in Amsterdam, beating <a href="Ukraine%20national%20football%20team">Ukraine</a> 3–2, <a href="Austria%20national%20football%20team">Austria</a> 2–0 and <a href="North%20Macedonia%20national%20football%20team">North Macedonia</a> 3–0. However, the tournament ended in disappointment for the Dutch once more, as they were beaten 2–0 by <a href="Czech%20Republic%20national%20football%20team">the Czech Republic</a> in their Round of 16 tie in <a href="Pusk%C3%A1s%20Ar%C3%A9na">Budapest</a>, after a <a href="Matthijs%20de%20Ligt">Matthijs de Ligt</a> <a href="Penalty%20card%23Red%20card">red card</a>. Two days later, De Boer left his position. He was replaced by Louis van Gaal, who came out of retirement to return for a third spell in charge of the side.
Team image.
Kits and crest.
The Netherlands national football team famously plays in bright orange shirts. Orange is the historic <a href="national%20colours">national colour</a> of the Netherlands, originating from one of the many titles of the ruling head of state, <a href="Prince%20of%20Orange">Prince of Orange</a>. The current Dutch away shirt is black. The lion on the crest is the Netherlands' national and royal animal and has been on the crest since 1907 when they won 3–1 over Belgium.
<a href="Nike%2C%20Inc.">Nike</a> is the national team's <a href="Kit%20%28association%20football%29">kit</a> provider, a sponsorship that began in 1996 and is contracted to continue until at least 2026. Before that the team was supplied by <a href="Adidas">Adidas</a> and <a href="Lotto%20Sport%20Italia">Lotto</a>.
Rivalries.
Deeply rooted in <a href="anti-German%20sentiment">anti-German sentiment</a> due to the <a href="History%20of%20the%20Netherlands%20%281939%E2%80%931945%29">occupation of the Netherlands by Germany</a> during World War II, the Netherlands' long-time football rival is Germany. Beginning in 1974, when the Dutch lost the 1974 World Cup to West Germany in the final, the rivalry between the two nations has become one of the best-known <a href="List%20of%20association%20football%20club%20rivalries%20by%20country">in international football</a>.
To a lesser extent, the Netherlands maintains a rivalry with their other neighbour, Belgium; a Belgium–Netherlands fixture is referred to as a <a href="Low%20Countries%20derby">Low Countries derby</a>. They have played in 126 matches with the two competing against each other regularly between 1905 and 1964. This has diminished due to the rise of semi-professional football.
Media coverage.
The Netherlands national football team matches have broadcast on <a href="Nederlandse%20Omroep%20Stichting">Nederlandse Omroep Stichting</a> which includes all friendlies, Nation League and <a href="FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification">World Cup qualifiers</a>. The newest contract is a four-year deal until 2022.
Home stadiums.
The Dutch national team does not have a national stadium but plays mostly at the <a href="Johan%20Cruyff%20Arena">Johan Cruyff Arena</a> in <a href="Amsterdam">Amsterdam</a>. It played host to the first Dutch international game back on March 29, 1997, with a <a href="1998%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%28UEFA%29">1998 World Cup qualification</a> match against <a href="San%20Marino%20national%20football%20team">San Marino</a> which the Netherlands won 4–0. It was formally called the Amsterdam Arena until 2018 when it was renamed in memory of Johan Cruyff.
Over the last few years, <a href="De%20Kuip">De Kuip</a> in <a href="Rotterdam">Rotterdam</a> has hosted matches more regularly. Occasionally, matches will take place at <a href="Philips%20Stadion">Philips Stadion</a> in <a href="Eindhoven">Eindhoven</a> and the <a href="De%20Grolsch%20Veste">De Grolsch Veste</a> in <a href="Enschede">Enschede</a>.
Results and fixtures.
The following matches were played or are scheduled to be played by the national team in the past or in the upcoming 12 months. The time in the Netherlands is shown first. If the local time is different, it will be displayed below.
Coaching staff.
Coaching history.
There has been thirty-eight different managers who have taken the role as manager of the Netherlands national football team with their first manager being <a href="Cees%20van%20Hasselt">Cees van Hasselt</a> in the first match against Belgium back in 1905. <a href="Bob%20Glendenning">Bob Glendenning</a> holds the record for being the longest in charge with sixteen years in charge of the national team between 1925 and 1940. He has also managed the Netherlands team the most times in history with 87 matches, twenty five more than second placed manager Dick Advocaat. Advocaat has the most wins as manager, with 37 to Glendenning's 36.

Competitive record.
FIFA World Cup.
The Netherlands' first two tournament appearances at the 1934 and the 1938 editions saw them lose their first round matches to Switzerland (1934) and Czechoslovakia (1938).
After not qualifying for the next six World Cups, they qualified for the 1974 FIFA World Cup in <a href="West%20Germany">West Germany</a>. There, with the use of "Total Football" tactics, they recorded their first win in World Cup competition against Uruguay. They qualified through to the second round where a win on the final match day secured the Netherlands a spot in the final. They lost to West Germany 2–1 with Gerd Müller scoring the winning goal for the Germans. The Netherlands once again made the <a href="1978%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1978 FIFA World Cup</a> final with the team finishing second in the group behind Peru. After finishing top of the all-European group in the second round, they met Argentina in the final. Argentina protested René van de Kerkhof's forearm plaster cast. After that protest, the game went to extra time where Argentina won 3–1 after scoring two goals in extra time.
The 1990 edition saw the Netherlands not win a single game throughout the tournament, scoring only two goals in the group stage. After finishing with an identical record with the Republic of Ireland, they were split by drawing of lots. The Dutch took on West Germany losing 2–1 in <a href="Milan">Milan</a>. 1994 saw the Netherlands knocked out in the quarter-final stage as they lost to eventual champions Brazil with <a href="Branco%20%28footballer%29">Branco</a>'s brutal free-kick sending them out. After qualifying from their group with five points, the Dutch made the semi finals of the 1998 edition where they once again lost to the Brazilians. This time it was by penalties; Phillip Cocu and Ronald de Boer's shots missed the goal to give Brazil a spot in the final. The Netherlands went on to finish in fourth place after losing to Croatia in the third-place playoff.
In 2006, the Netherlands made it to the round of 16 where, in what was called the "Battle of Nuremberg" they lost by a single goal to Portugal. The Dutch were given seven yellow cards. The following edition, in 2010, saw the team qualify to the knockout stage by finishing atop Group E. After defeating Slovakia 2–1 in the round of 16, they came back from an early goal by <a href="Robinho">Robinho</a> to defeat Brazil 2–1 in the quarter-finals as Wesley Sneijder scored a double. In the semi-final, they defeated Uruguay in a tough game for the Dutch, making their first World Cup final since 1978. In the final, they took on Spain. During normal time, the Dutch had plenty of chances to win the game, the closest being in the 62nd minute when Sneijder shot wide. Spain's winning goal came off a play in the 116th minute after the Netherlands went down to ten men.
In 2014, the Netherlands finish atop Group B with wins over Spain, Australia and Chile. In the round of 16 match against Mexico, the Netherlands came back from a goal down to manage a 2–1 win in stoppage time with Klaas-Jan Huntelaar scoring a controversial penalty. In the quarter-finals, they defeated Costa Rica on penalties however they lost to Argentina on penalties in the semi-final. The Netherlands took bronze in the tournament after defeating host nation Brazil 3–0 in the third-place playoff.
